The ACA is working. Census data shows that only 8.6 percent of people in California went uninsured in 2015. That is down from 18.5 percent in 2010! That dramatic drop means 3.8 million more Californians had coverage last year, and I pledge to do everything in my power to protect our coverage.

The Federal Communications Commission works with internet providers to help low-income households receive better, high-speed broadband access. But last week, FCC Chair Ajit Pai blocked nine companies from doing so. I took to the House floor and discussed why it should be easier for low-income families to get affordable, fast internet access, not more difficult. Chairman Pai’s actions are just another example of the Trump administration putting corporate interests ahead of that of the public.
Let us know if you can attend the town hall meeting in Fremont on February 22. Would be great to see you there.

Yesterday, I spoke on the importance of restructuring the rules of our economy and giving power back to workers and joined my colleagues from the House and the Senate. It is unfair to say to workers -- who are struggling with stagnant wages and rising family costs -- that we must choose between economic growth and a $15 minimum wage. Economic growth and higher wages go hand-in-hand. And any wage increase should not be limited to the private sector. We must pay workers a living wage and provide them with job benefits such as overtime, paid leave, and affordable health care.

We need to respect the extraordinary contributions of coal workers and have policies to ensure they have good wages, safety, and a middle class life and retirement. But we also need to help prepare the next generation for the jobs of the future and make sure they have equal access to tech jobs. I am excited to go to Appalachia in a few weeks to highlight a program that is training coal miners' kids on IOS software for four months on the iPhone. We need to offer every community real opportunities for tech jobs.

The Affordable Care Act provides more than 20 million people with health insurance and its protections allow fewer than 10 percent of the population to remain uninsured. However, congressional Republicans plan to halt the progress, including cancelling preventative services and consumer protections covered in the law, freezing Medicaid expansion for low and moderate income families and individuals, and defunding Planned Parenthood.  The reality is that the health care tax credits Republicans are offering are not sufficient for millions of working families to afford decent insurance. Also, their plan will result in a rise in premiums for those with pre-existing conditions as healthy individuals opt out of the system.   Ultimately, we need a single payer health care system and Medicare for all. That is the vision I will fight for during my time in Congress.

13 years ago, Lori from San Jose was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer that ultimately required 5 surgeries and 8 rounds of chemo to beat. Because she has a family history of cancer, Lori was proactive about her health care prior to the diagnosis and got regular checkups and mammograms, which she credits with saving her life. After treatment, she was tested for the BRCA gene mutation and learned that as a carrier, she has an 87% chance of developing breast cancer and a 50% chance of developing ovarian cancer. Lori worries that under the #GOPHealthcareBill, having a genetic mutation could be considered a preexisting condition. Lori knows that genetic testing can lead to behaviors that help catch diseases in their early stages, meaning the difference between life and death. She also knows that if people are denied access to healthcare based on genetics, they will die. As science advances and we develop new tools to evaluate risk, we must make sure that these tools are used to provide better care, not deny it. I’m fighting for Lori and her family. The ACA restriction on insurance providers denying health insurance based on pre-existing conditions must stay in place.

Today, I had the honor of recognizing the life of World War II hero and U.S. ally, Chinese General Sun Li-jen, on the House floor. General Sun died at the age of 91 in 1990, but his legacy lives on among the Chinese American community. General Sun is internationally renowned for his extraordinary service during the Battle of Yenangyaung in 1942, where he saved the British First Burma Division from the Imperial Japanese Army. He found greater strength as a leader by combining Eastern and Western ideas and his accomplishments demonstrated that we are better when we embrace diversity. We must ensure living wages, healthcare, and affordable housing for ALL members of the Silicon Valley community. I will continue to fight for measures that support working Americans, like Medicare for All and a massive expansion of/ the earned income tax credit -- the GAIN Act.

The President and his party has tried every trick in the book to undermine the Affordable Care Act. I am proud to be an original cosponsor of this bill that would bring high-speed internet access to underserved parts of the country. Access to high-speed internet is not optional. This bill would make sure that every American has access to good, quality internet connection, and bridge the inequalities in internet access across the country.

Great catching up with SEIU leader Debbie over coffee in Fremont. Thanks for sharing the latest on labor news and priorities in #CA17.  I also enjoyed talking to Californians at the California State Society breakfast last week in Washington. Thanks for having me.

This piece offers a clear picture. The GOP tax plan “hurts the poor and increases the deficit,” and gives money back to the wealthiest Americans and corporations. We must continue to oppose this misguided plan and stand up for the American working middle class.

Our country derives its strength from its diversity. This Transgender Awareness Week, we celebrate our #transgender community members and their accomplishments in the face of adversity. Here’s the bottom line when it comes to taxes: the Republican plan bets on the investor class. We bet on you – the American middle class.

The misguided GOP tax plan will make graduate education more expensive and discourage our students from pursuing advanced degrees and research, making America less innovative and less competitive on the world stage. It is incredibly disheartening to see GOP leaders prioritize tax cuts for the rich over our students and our future.

My friend and colleague, Congressman Jodey Arrington, and I, wrote an oped on our bipartisan veterans bill, the VALOR Act, which passed the House and the Senate This bill will cut through VA red tape and make apprenticeship programs much more accessible for our veterans, making it easier for our nation’s veterans to get the skills they need for 21st-century jobs.

Mission College is having an open house event this upcoming weekend on Saturday, Nov. 18. Come learn more about Mission College’s academic programs and find out how it can help you achieve your educational goals.

Smart marijuana policy makes our communities safer, opens up jobs, and provides economic growth. Bad marijuana laws have had a disproportionate effect on communities of color. With their passion and leadership, teachers pave the way for our future generations. Lower income families are doing worse, not better. According to Census data, the average American household income for the bottom 20% of Americans fell $571 between 2006 and 2016, while to top 20% GREW BY $13,749. The GOP tax bill is a disgrace and is a big step in the wrong direction.

Unilateral military interventions are counterproductive to our strategic goals, and prolong violence and suffering. The President has not filled key positions, and his appointment of cabinet officials without proper experience has decimated morale. Congressman John Conyers, Jr. and Sen. Al Franken have done the right thing by choosing to resign. Their actions are a step towards changing the culture that has permitted sexual assault and sexual harassment for too long.

Five years ago today, 26 innocent people, including 20 children, lost their lives at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut.
